title: Jeremiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 10.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10:2, what should the house of Israel not learn?
questions.correctAnswer: The way of the heathen
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:2 instructs the house of Israel not to learn the way of the heathen.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 10:3, what is cut from the forest?
questions.correctAnswer: A tree
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:3 states that a tree is cut out of the forest by the workman.

questions.question: What do the people deck the tree with according to Jeremiah 10:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:4 says they deck the tree with silver and gold.

questions.question: What is said about the tree in Jeremiah 10:5?
options: They are upright as the palm tree but speak not
They grow tall and speak wisdom
They bear fruit and do good
questions.correctAnswer: They are upright as the palm tree but speak not
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:5 describes the tree as upright as the palm tree but it does not speak and must be carried.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10:6, how is the LORD described?
options: Great, with a great name in might
questions.correctAnswer: Great, with a great name in might
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:6 says there is none like the LORD; He is great and His name is great in might.

questions.question: Who would fear the LORD according to Jeremiah 10:7?
options: The wise men of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The King of nations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:7 expresses that the King of nations is to be feared, and none among the wise men is like Him.

questions.question: Where is silver brought from according to Jeremiah 10:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Tarshish
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:9 states that silver is spread into plates and brought from Tarshish.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10:10, who is the true God?
options: The LORD, the living God and everlasting king
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD, the living God and everlasting king
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:10 declares the LORD as the true God, living and everlasting king.

questions.question: What shall perish from the earth according to Jeremiah 10:11?
options: The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:11 states that the gods which did not make the heavens and earth shall perish.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 10:14 says every founder is confident in his graven image.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:14 states every founder is confounded by the graven image, not confident.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 10:16 says Israel is the rod of God's inheritance.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:16 states that Israel is the rod of God's inheritance.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 10:21 states that the pastors have sought the LORD diligently.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:21 says the pastors are brutish and have not sought the LORD.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Jeremiah 10:23: 'O LORD, I know that the way of man is not in ______:'
questions.correctAnswer: himself
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:23 says the way of man is not in himself.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say has been spoiled according to Jeremiah 10:20?
questions.correctAnswer: His tabernacle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:20 states that his tabernacle is spoiled and all his cords are broken.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10:13, what does God bring forth from his treasures?
questions.correctAnswer: The wind
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:13 says God bringeth forth the wind out of his treasures.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of natural phenomena. Based on Jeremiah 10, what biblical truth would you share to encourage faith and trust?
options: Do not be afraid of the signs in heaven, for God is the living God who controls all
Fear the natural elements because they are powerful gods
Worship the stars and signs in heaven to gain protection
Ignore God's power and trust only in human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be afraid of the signs in heaven, for God is the living God who controls all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:2 teaches not to be dismayed at the signs of heaven because God is the living God (Jeremiah 10:10) who controls the earth and heavens (Jeremiah 10:12-13). This encourages trust rather than fear.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 instruct believers regarding the use of idols and images in worship?
options: Idols are vain and lifeless, made by human hands and cannot do good or evil
Idols have power to protect and bless believers
Idols are living gods that must be worshiped
Idols should be made with silver and gold for greater power
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are vain and lifeless, made by human hands and cannot do good or evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:3-5 explains idols are cut from trees and decorated but cannot speak or move; they do no good nor evil. Verses 14-15 emphasize they are false and without breath.

questions.question: In a family setting, how does Jeremiah 10 teach about the importance of recognizing God's uniqueness?
options: There is none like the LORD; He is great in might and worthy of reverence
Many gods exist and should be honored equally
God is only one among many powerful beings
God's name is not important in family worship
questions.correctAnswer: There is none like the LORD; He is great in might and worthy of reverence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:6-7 emphasize God's incomparable greatness and the reverence He deserves, teaching families to trust and worship the one true God.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to follow worldly customs that contradict God's Word. According to Jeremiah 10, what principle should guide their behavior?
options: Do not learn the way of the heathen because their customs are vain
Follow all customs to fit in with society
Ignore God's warnings and trust human traditions
Embrace customs that seem popular even if they contradict Scripture
questions.correctAnswer: Do not learn the way of the heathen because their customs are vain
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:2-3 warns against learning the ways of heathen nations because their customs are empty and vain, encouraging obedience to God instead.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty in daily life?
options: Idols are false and the work of errors; trust in the true God who made all things
Dishonest work can produce powerful gods
Honesty is irrelevant when making images or idols
Integrity comes from following traditions, not God's word
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are false and the work of errors; trust in the true God who made all things
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 describe idols as vanity and error, contrasting with God’s truth (verses 10, 12), teaching believers to live with integrity by trusting God’s reality rather than falsehood.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God's sovereignty can a believer learn from Jeremiah 10 when facing trials?
options: The LORD is an everlasting king whose wrath makes the earth tremble
Human wisdom controls the outcome of trials
Trials come from false gods and should be accepted passively
God is weak and cannot control nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is an everlasting king whose wrath makes the earth tremble
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:10 highlights God's power and sovereignty during trials, teaching believers to trust His might and justice in difficult times.

questions.question: A believer asks why idols cannot save or help. How does Jeremiah 10 explain this?
options: Idols have no breath or life and are made by human hands, so they cannot help
Idols have secret powers but choose not to act
Idols are living beings that only help sometimes
Idols are gods who punish disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: Idols have no breath or life and are made by human hands, so they cannot help
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:14 explains that founders are confounded by their graven images because idols are false and have no breath, making them incapable of help.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 teach about prayer and calling on God's name?
options: Heathen who do not know or call on God will face His fury
Prayer is unnecessary because idols can answer
Only kings should pray to God
Calling on God's name has no impact on one's life
questions.correctAnswer: Heathen who do not know or call on God will face His fury
questions.explanation: Verse 25 instructs to pour out God's fury on those who do not know or call on His name, implying the importance of calling on God in prayer and devotion.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 10 says that human beings can direct their own steps without God's guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:23 states that the way of man is not in himself and he cannot direct his own steps, emphasizing dependence on God's guidance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 10, the pastors who do not seek the Lord will prosper and keep their flocks safe.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:21 says that pastors who have become brutish and have not sought the LORD will not prosper, and their flocks will be scattered.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 10 teaches that God created the earth by his _____, established the world by his _____, and stretched out the heavens by his _____.
questions.correctAnswer: power, wisdom, discretion
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:12 clearly states God made the earth by his power, established the world by his wisdom, and stretched out the heavens by his discretion.

questions.question: How should believers respond to the vanity of earthly idols and customs according to Jeremiah 10?
options: Reject vain customs and trust in the living God who sustains all
Adopt all customs as equally valid
Worship idols for protection and blessing
Ignore God's Word and follow popular traditions
questions.correctAnswer: Reject vain customs and trust in the living God who sustains all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:3-5 and 10:10-12 contrast vain idols with the living God, encouraging believers to reject empty customs and rely on God.

questions.question: A believer is weary and grieving over loss. Based on Jeremiah 10, what biblical truth about God's correction and judgment can offer hope?
options: God corrects with judgment but not in anger to avoid destruction
God punishes without mercy leading to ruin
God's correction is always harsh and final
questions.correctAnswer: God corrects with judgment but not in anger to avoid destruction
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:24 shows a prayer asking God to correct with judgment but not in anger to prevent being brought to nothing, offering hope in discipline.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 teach about the responsibility of God's people regarding their possessions during times of distress?
options: Gather up your wares and prepare because the inhabitants will be slung out
Ignore material possessions and trust that God will protect them
Build idols to safeguard your possessions
Keep possessions regardless of warning signs
questions.correctAnswer: Gather up your wares and prepare because the inhabitants will be slung out
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:17-18 instructs inhabitants to gather their wares as God will distress and remove them, teaching prudent preparation aligned with God’s warnings.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 encourage believers to view their inheritance and identity in God compared to false gods?
options: Jacob’s portion is unique because the LORD of hosts is his name and the former of all things
Jacob’s inheritance is like the idols made by men
Identity is formed by following the customs of the heathen
Inheritance depends on human wisdom and power
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob’s portion is unique because the LORD of hosts is his name and the former of all things
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:16 contrasts Jacob’s inheritance as unique because God is the creator and LORD of hosts, encouraging believers to find identity in God.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 10.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 10, what is the LORD’s command concerning the customs of the heathen?
options: Learn not the way of the heathen
Adopt the customs of the heathen
Celebrate the signs of heaven like the heathen
Ignore the word of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Learn not the way of the heathen
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:2 instructs Israel not to learn the ways of the heathen, emphasizing separation from pagan customs.

questions.question: What is the significance of the tree cut out of the forest described in Jeremiah 10?
options: It represents the vanity of idolatrous practices
It symbolizes the strength of Israel
It is a metaphor for the LORD’s creation
It depicts the growth of the palm tree
questions.correctAnswer: It represents the vanity of idolatrous practices
questions.explanation: Verse 3 highlights the vanity of pagan customs by describing how a man cuts a tree to make an idol, illustrating the futility of idolatry.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10, what are the idols incapable of doing?
questions.correctAnswer: Doing good or evil
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that idols cannot do evil nor good, emphasizing their lifeless and powerless nature.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 describe the LORD in contrast to idols?
options: The LORD is the living God and an everlasting king
The LORD is silent and immovable
The LORD is a crafted image of silver and gold
The LORD is like the palm tree
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the living God and an everlasting king
questions.explanation: Verse 10 contrasts idols with the LORD, who is described as the living God and eternal king, highlighting His divine power.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Jeremiah 10:6-7 to emphasize God's uniqueness?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verses use parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to reinforce God’s unparalleled greatness among nations and wise men.

questions.question: What is the significance of the reference to silver from Tarshish and gold from Uphaz in Jeremiah 10?
options: It highlights the craftsmanship and value of idols
It points to the wealth of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the craftsmanship and value of idols
questions.explanation: Verse 9 mentions these precious metals to emphasize the elaborate but futile efforts in idol-making by skilled craftsmen.

questions.question: What theological theme in Jeremiah 10 is foreshadowed by the description of God's voice causing waters and winds?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign control over creation
questions.explanation: Verse 13 uses imagery of natural forces controlled by God's voice, foreshadowing His ultimate authority over all creation.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10, what happens to the gods that did not make the heavens and earth?
options: They shall perish from the earth
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish from the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states that false gods who did not create the heavens and earth will perish, affirming monotheism.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the phrase 'the portion of Jacob' in Jeremiah 10:16?
options: The land of Canaan given to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Israel as God’s chosen inheritance
questions.explanation: Verse 16 identifies Jacob’s portion as Israel, God's chosen people, contrasting them with false idols.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 10, what is the condition of the ‘pastors’ or leaders according to the text?
options: They have become brutish and have not sought the LORD
They lead with wisdom and righteousness
They are faithful to God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: They have become brutish and have not sought the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 21 criticizes the leaders for their foolishness and failure to seek God, resulting in scattered flocks.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10:23 express the human condition in relation to divine guidance?
options: Man cannot direct his own steps without the LORD
Man is fully capable of self-direction
Man’s way is perfect in himself
questions.correctAnswer: Man cannot direct his own steps without the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 23 acknowledges human inability to guide oneself properly, underscoring dependency on God.

questions.question: What is the emotional tone of Jeremiah 10:19–20, and how does it relate to the historical context?
options: Grief and loss reflecting the exile and destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Grief and loss reflecting the exile and destruction
questions.explanation: The verses express deep sorrow over loss of homeland and family, corresponding to the impending Babylonian exile.

questions.question: Which New Testament concept is foreshadowed by Jeremiah 10's emphasis on the LORD as the living God and everlasting king?
options: Christ as the eternal King and living God
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the eternal King and living God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:10’s portrayal of God anticipates the New Testament revelation of Jesus as the eternal, living King.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 10 depicts idols as living beings with breath and power to act.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 14 clearly states idols have no breath and are falsehoods, emphasizing their lifelessness.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of the repeated use of the word 'brutish' in Jeremiah 10?
options: To emphasize foolishness and lack of understanding
To describe the strength of idols
To highlight the wisdom of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize foolishness and lack of understanding
questions.explanation: The term 'brutish' in verses 8, 14, and 21 underscores the folly of idol makers, idol worshipers, and leaders who fail to seek God.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10, what is the LORD's command regarding the customs of the heathen?
options: Learn not the way of the heathen
Adopt the customs of the heathen
Fear the gods of the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: Learn not the way of the heathen
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:2 explicitly commands Israel to 'Learn not the way of the heathen.' This teaches the biblical principle of holiness and separation from pagan practices (Leviticus 20:23, Romans 12:2, 1 Corinthians 10:20, Ephesians 5:11).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say about the idols made by human hands?
options: They are vanity and the work of errors
They have breath and can speak
questions.correctAnswer: They are vanity and the work of errors
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:15 states that graven images are 'vanity, and the work of errors,' emphasizing their futility and falsehood. This aligns with Psalm 135:15-18, Isaiah 44:9-20, Habakkuk 2:18-19, and Acts 17:29 which critique idolatry as powerless and senseless.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 describe the LORD in contrast to idols?
options: The LORD is the living God and an everlasting king
The LORD is silent and inactive
The LORD is one among many gods
The LORD is made by human hands
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the living God and an everlasting king
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:10 declares that the LORD is 'the living God, and an everlasting king.' This affirms God's eternal sovereignty and life-giving power, consistent with Deuteronomy 33:27, Isaiah 40:28, Revelation 1:8, and Psalm 90:2.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say about the ability of idols to do good or evil?
options: They cannot do evil nor do good
questions.correctAnswer: They cannot do evil nor do good
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:5 teaches that idols 'cannot do evil, neither also is it in them to do good,' highlighting their impotence. This idea is supported by Psalm 115:4-8, Isaiah 44:18, Habakkuk 2:18, and 1 Corinthians 8:4-6 which emphasize God’s unique and active nature in contrast to idols.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 10, why should Israel not fear the idols?
options: Because they cannot move or speak
Because they are more powerful than God
Because they come alive at night
questions.correctAnswer: Because they cannot move or speak
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:5 notes that idols 'speak not' and 'must needs be borne, because they cannot go,' meaning they are lifeless and immobile. This underscores the biblical truth found in Isaiah 46:5-7 and Psalm 135:15-18 that idols lack power and life.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say about the origin of the earth and heavens?
options: They were made by the LORD’s power and wisdom
They were made by the gods of the heathen
They were created by human hands
questions.correctAnswer: They were made by the LORD’s power and wisdom
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:12 states that God 'hath made the earth by his power, he hath established the world by his wisdom, and hath stretched out the heavens by his discretion.' This affirms God as Creator consistent with Genesis 1:1, Psalm 33:6-9, Isaiah 40:26, and Hebrews 11:3.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say happens when the LORD utters His voice?
options: There is a multitude of waters and He brings forth wind from His treasures
questions.correctAnswer: There is a multitude of waters and He brings forth wind from His treasures
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:13 describes that when God speaks, 'there is a multitude of waters in the heavens,' and He 'bringeth forth the wind out of his treasures.' This imagery of divine power over creation parallels Psalm 29:3-9, Job 37:1-13, and Nahum 1:3.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 10 describe the wisdom of idol makers?
questions.correctAnswer: They are brutish and foolish
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:8 characterizes idol makers as 'altogether brutish and foolish,' highlighting their ignorance despite their craft. This is consistent with Isaiah 44:9-20 and Psalm 115:4-8 which portray idol makers as deceived and deceivers.

questions.question: What is the fate of gods that have not made the heavens and the earth, according to Jeremiah 10?
options: They shall perish from the earth and under the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish from the earth and under the heavens
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:11 proclaims that gods who did not create the heavens and earth 'shall perish from the earth, and from under these heavens.' This aligns with biblical teaching in Isaiah 37:16, Psalm 96:5, and 1 Corinthians 8:4-6 affirming the Lord as the only true God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The portion of Jacob is not like them: for he is the former of all things; and Israel is the ____ of his inheritance.'
questions.correctAnswer: rod
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:16 states that Israel is the 'rod of his inheritance,' symbolizing God's chosen instrument. This connects with biblical imagery of the rod or staff as a symbol of authority and care (Psalm 23:4, Isaiah 11:1, Hebrews 7:14).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say about the knowledge of every man and founder regarding idols?
options: Every man is brutish in his knowledge and every founder is confounded
questions.correctAnswer: Every man is brutish in his knowledge and every founder is confounded
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:14 highlights human folly in idolatry by saying 'Every man is brutish in his knowledge: every founder is confounded by the graven image.' This theme is echoed in Isaiah 44:20 and Romans 1:21-23 where human wisdom is shown as futile apart from God.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Jeremiah 10 for the scattering of flocks and the failure of pastors?
options: The pastors have become brutish and have not sought the LORD
The land is cursed by God
questions.correctAnswer: The pastors have become brutish and have not sought the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:21 states that pastors are 'become brutish, and have not sought the LORD,' resulting in scattered flocks. This reflects the biblical principle that spiritual leaders must seek God (Ezekiel 34:1-10, Hebrews 13:17, 1 Peter 5:2-3).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 say about the 'noise of the bruit' and its effect on Judah?
options: It brings great commotion making the cities desolate
It causes joy among the people
questions.correctAnswer: It brings great commotion making the cities desolate
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:22 warns that the noise from the north will cause 'great commotion' and make 'the cities of Judah desolate.' This prophecy of invasion and desolation is consistent with later judgments described in Ezekiel 7:26, Isaiah 10:5-6, and Lamentations 2:1-9.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 10 request from the LORD in verse 24?
options: Correct me with judgment, not in anger
questions.correctAnswer: Correct me with judgment, not in anger
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:24 petitions God for correction 'with judgment; not in thine anger,' showing a plea for merciful discipline. This reflects the biblical theme of God’s loving correction (Proverbs 3:11-12, Hebrews 12:5-11, Psalm 94:12).

questions.question: What is the consequence for the heathen and families that do not know or call on the LORD, as stated in Jeremiah 10?
options: They will be visited by God's fury and their consumption
questions.correctAnswer: They will be visited by God's fury and their consumption
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 10:25 pronounces that God's fury will be poured upon heathen who do not know Him, as they have 'eaten up Jacob' and made his habitation desolate. This aligns with the justice of God against the wicked (Nahum 1:2-3, Romans 1:18, Psalm 2:5).
